content: Indranil Gupta : UIUC Home Page Indranil Gupta Professor, Department of Computer Science; & Affiliate Faculty, Department of ECE, ITI, Beckman Institute; @ University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign. IEEE Fellow, ACM Distinguished Member [Podcast] [Teaching] [PhD Students] [Research and Papers] [News Articles] [Service] [CV, Awards, and Bio] [Contact] [Hobbies] Podcast I host the (free) podcast Immigrant Computer Scientists. Listen to personal stories (oral histories) of immigration from prominent and distinguished Computer Scientists from academia and industry, who immigrated from their home countries to the US. Subscribe and listen for free on Apple Podcasts, Google Podcasts, Spotify, and nearly all podcast outlets. New Episodes every week from Aug 26th, 2021 and onwards! Check it out! Episode guides available at the website for Immigrant Computer Scientists. Join the online discussion on Twitter and Facebook. Throughout 2021 and 2022, the podcast has ranked among the top 20% of podcasts in the world! (based on listener download numbers). Teaching Current CS425 / ECE 428 - Distributed Systems [Fall 2025] This year the school/department is unable to maintain a waitlist. Please do not email us to give you an override. In the past everyone (on campus) who wanted to get in, has managed (though there's no guarantees). Please continue submitting HWs and MPs. If you can't register by the end of September, email Indy. The school has informed us that we cannot approve double-booking CS425 with another class. This is due to limitations of final exam logistics. Please do not email us asking for overrides/conflict approval. This class has multiple sections: 3 cr on-campus (no MPs), 4 cr on-campus (with MPs), MCS Chicago (3cr and 4cr), and online (Coursera: 3cr and 4cr). Generally undergrads and graduate students (and in each 3cr and 4cr) are curved separately at semester end. This is an introductory course on distributed systems. Programming assignments involve building a real, working, cloud computing system, in several stages. Pre-/co-requisites include: OS or networking, and (for on-campus MPs) basic sockets programming. A class of 50+ graduate (and undergraduate) students reviews, presents, and debates about 80 papers. Projects are either entrepreneurial ventures, or are research-oriented - the course has a strong history of having its projects published in conferences and journals.
